items.keywords: predictions, future, engineering
items.articleName: Inside the Future: How PopMech Predicted the Next 110 Years
items.articleTeaser: PM has never been shy about forecasting the future, though we've had a few misses to go along with our hits. Here, PopMech Editor-in-Chief Jim Meigs explains why we decided to use the magazine's 110th anniversary to predict the breakthroughs of the next 110 years, and reveals the brain trust that helped us do it.

items.keywords: forget, small, boosted, V6A, turbocharged, future of engines
items.articleName: Forget the V6—Small Engines are the Future
items.articleTeaser: They used to say "There's no replacement for displacement." But that's not true anymore. Engines are downsizing, but thanks to the explosion of turbos and tech like electric boost, you might not even notice the difference when you hit the gas.

items.keywords: cars, future, performance, automobiles, michelin, michelin challenge
items.articleName: The Vehicles of the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum
items.articleTeaser: PM traveled to Berlin to see the hardware on hand at the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum, a wild event that's part auto show and part science fair.

items.keywords: cars, future, performance, automobiles, michelin, michelin challenge
items.articleName: The Vehicles of the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum
items.articleTeaser: PM traveled to Berlin to see the hardware on hand at the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum, a wild event that's part auto show and part science fair.

items.keywords: cars, future, performance, automobiles, michelin, michelin challenge
items.articleName: The Vehicles of the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum
items.articleTeaser: PM traveled to Berlin to see the hardware on hand at the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum, a wild event that's part auto show and part science fair.

items.articleName: The Vehicles of the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum

items.keywords: cars, future, performance, automobiles, michelin, michelin challenge
items.articleName: The Vehicles of the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum
items.articleTeaser: PM traveled to Berlin to see the hardware on hand at the 2011 Michelin Challenge Bibendum, a wild event that's part auto show and part science fair.

items.keywords: breakthrough, electric, automobile, awards, panels, future
items.articleName: What Is the Future of the Electric Automobile?
items.articleTeaser: With the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf each receiving Popular Mechanics' highest honors this year, our Breakthrough Award panel discussion on the future of automobiles focused on electric cars.

items.keywords: iceberg, future, forensics, ice, antarctic, environment
items.articleName: Iceberg Forensics: Predicting the Planet's Future With Antarctic Ice
items.articleTeaser: In the last million years, the North American ice sheet has formed and completely melted about 10 times. Ice is melting once again—simultaneously, across the globe—and the science research vessel and drilling ship JOIDES Resolution has been seeking out clues to how ice sheets may respond to a warming climate. Onboard in Antarctica, Trevor Williams reports on the role that ice has played throughout geologic history and what a new iceberg in the Southern Ocean can tell us about the future for the planet.

items.keywords: shaping, projects, LED, future of lights, environmentally friendly
items.articleName: 17 Projects Shaping the Future of LED Lights
items.articleTeaser: Solid-state lighting holds the promise of huge energy savings and long-lasting light sources. But before it comes to market, the products, like LED lights, have to get better, cheaper and easier to make. Here's how the U.S. Department of Energy is investing in a future illuminated by light-emitting diodes (LEDs) and organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs).

items.keywords: Space Station, Space, Space Shuttle, Future of Space, Nasa, Private Space, Buzz Aldrin
items.articleName: 8 Experts Weigh in on the Future of Human Spaceflight
items.articleTeaser: The Review of U.S. Human Space Flight Planes Committee is getting ready to release its full report detailing the options for the future of manned missions into space. While the discussion over the future of NASA continues, PM turned to the leading rocketeers, astronauts and manufacturers to weigh in on the debate.

items.keywords: Burt rutan, Space, Mojave, Aviation, Spacecraft, Future Of Space, NASA, Aircraft
items.articleName: New Area 51: Mojave's Desert Outpost Holds Space Flight's Future
items.articleTeaser: With mysterious test flights, secret prototypes and next-gen spacecraft, this remote California airfield became the hotbed of rebel aerospace. Welcome to Mojave Air and Space Port, where aviation's iconoclasts are granted the headroom to make history.

items.keywords: Highway of the future, GPS, Vehicale Infrastructure Integration, Intelligent Vehicle Initative, Interstate Intelligence, Active Traffic Management, Automated Highway System
items.articleName: Highway of the Future: Interstate Intelligence
items.articleTeaser: Our nation’s highways are being primed for a major transformation, one that will bring them into the wireless information age.

items.keywords: Future, Flying, Shield For America's, Missle
items.articleName: The Flying Future for America's Missile Shield
items.articleTeaser: This week the Obama administration said that it will likely scale back plans to install ground-based missile defense interceptors in Poland and the Czech Republic. While the Iranian long-range rocket threat is now downgraded, missile defense interceptors are still part of U.S. military strategy. The move away from ground-based interceptors in Europe could signal a technological shift—to the air. Could air-launched interceptors be the answer for missile defense?

items.keywords: Future, Flying, Shield For America's, Missle
items.articleName: The Flying Future for America's Missile Shield
items.articleTeaser: This week the Obama administration said that it will likely scale back plans to install ground-based missile defense interceptors in Poland and the Czech Republic. While the Iranian long-range rocket threat is now downgraded, missile defense interceptors are still part of U.S. military strategy. The move away from ground-based interceptors in Europe could signal a technological shift—to the air. Could air-launched interceptors be the answer for missile defense?

items.keywords: Space, Nasa, Ares, Space_Shuttle, Tom_Jones, Spacecraft, Future Of Space
items.articleName: NASA & Its Discontents: Frustrated Engineers Battle with NASA over the Future of Spaceflight
items.articleTeaser: A group of renegade space vehicle designers, including NASA engineers bucking their bosses, are publicly crying out against the current Shuttle retirement plan. Their proposed plan, called Jupiter Direct, is an affront to NASA's current plans for the Ares I rocket, which they say is more costly and time-consuming than it needs to be. This is their story.

items.keywords: Space, Nasa, Ares, Space_Shuttle, Tom_Jones, Spacecraft, Future Of Space
items.articleName: NASA & Its Discontents: Frustrated Engineers Battle with NASA over the Future of Spaceflight
items.articleTeaser: A group of renegade space vehicle designers, including NASA engineers bucking their bosses, are publicly crying out against the current Shuttle retirement plan. Their proposed plan, called Jupiter Direct, is an affront to NASA's current plans for the Ares I rocket, which they say is more costly and time-consuming than it needs to be. This is their story.

items.keywords: Space, Nasa, Ares, Space_Shuttle, Tom_Jones, Spacecraft, Future Of Space
items.articleName: NASA & Its Discontents: Frustrated Engineers Battle with NASA over the Future of Spaceflight
items.articleTeaser: A group of renegade space vehicle designers, including NASA engineers bucking their bosses, are publicly crying out against the current Shuttle retirement plan. Their proposed plan, called Jupiter Direct, is an affront to NASA's current plans for the Ares I rocket, which they say is more costly and time-consuming than it needs to be. This is their story.

items.keywords: Future Of Space, Space, Moon, Questions, Buzz Aldrin, Nasa, Astronauts, Spacecraft
items.articleName: 7 New Questions on the Future of Mars and Private Space for Buzz Aldrin
items.articleTeaser: NASA's Apollo 11 mission is nearing its 40th anniversary, but former astronaut Buzz Aldrin has made a second career of keeping his eyes on the future. Whether he's charting a mission to Mars or getting a first look at the newest spacecraft from private industry, Aldrin isn't afraid to go against the grain. On tour for the new 3D movie Fly Me to the Moon, Aldrin (a member of PM's editorial board of advisers) recently stopped by the offices of Popular Mechanics to meet with editors and executives—and to take a moment to talk about life on Mars, lessons from the Russian and Chinese space programs and a lottery for space tourism.

items.keywords: Boeing, missile_defense, North_Korea, lasers, missiles
items.articleName: Star Wars Reborn: The Airborne Laser
items.articleTeaser:
Although rumors of its death have been greatly exaggerated, the embattled, multibillion-dollar Airborne Laser is fighting for its life. The most powerful battlefield laser in development, and one of the most ambitious weapon systems to date, the Airborne Laser is designed to prove that a megawatt-class chemical laser mounted on a large aircraft (in this case, a 747) can shoot down a long-range ballistic missile before it escapes the atmosphere. Critics have long derided every aspect of the project, from its cost overruns to the limited scope and Hollywood overtones of its proposed mission. What nation would be reckless enough to launch a missile at the United States, and foolish enough to telegraph the blow, providing the advance warning necessary to deploy a laser-armed 747? 

Read more: Experts See Divergent Futures for Boeing's Two Flying Lasers - Popular Mechanics 
Follow us: @PopMech on Twitter | popularmechanics on Facebook 
Visit us at PopularMechanics.com

items.keywords: Future, Generation, DIY, Mentor
items.articleName: 6 Inspiring Mentors Teaching the Next DIY Generation
items.articleTeaser: Setting rivets, sawing lumber, soldering circuits—mentors from Maryland to Alaska teach kids skills like these to build robots, homes, and brighter futures.

items.articleName: 6 Inspiring Mentors Teaching the Next DIY Generation
items.articleTeaser: Setting rivets, sawing lumber, soldering circuits—mentors from Maryland to Alaska teach kids skills like these to build robots, homes, and brighter futures.

items.articleName: 6 Inspiring Mentors Teaching the Next DIY Generation
items.articleTeaser: Setting rivets, sawing lumber, soldering circuits—mentors from Maryland to Alaska teach kids skills like these to build robots, homes, and brighter futures.

While the discussion over the future of NASA continues, PM turned to the leading rocketeers, astronauts and manufacturers to weigh in on the debate.

items.keywords: predictions, future, engineering
items.articleName: Maybe NASA Won't Grab That Asteroid
items.articleTeaser: President Obama's plan for NASA to capture an asteroid gets bogged down in Congress.

items.keywords: nasa, atmosphere, ER-2, aviation, DC-8, SEAC4RS
items.articleName: NASA's Flying Labs Take to the Skies
items.articleTeaser: Planes, satellites, and scientists scan the southern U.S. for climate change insight.

items.keywords: mason peck, sci-fi, nasa
items.articleName: Dad Advice from NASA's Mason Peck
items.articleTeaser: Fresh off a wildly popular Reddit AMA, NASA CTO Mason Peck tells PopMech what he learned from his science-fiction-writer dad. (Check back for more dad advice from PopMech's Fatherhood Issue, leading up to our full list—127 Things My Dad Taught Me.)

items.keywords: telescopes, KEPLER, Kepler telescope, nasa, planets, exoplanets, Kepler mission
items.articleName: Can Kepler, NASA's Planet-Hunter, Be Saved?
items.articleTeaser: Two broken reaction wheels have paralyzed NASA's premier planet-hunting telescope. Can it be salvaged?

items.keywords: movie, Space Shuttle, Digital Hollywood, star trek into darkness, nasa, apollo, star trek
items.articleName: NASA Ad to Run Before Star Trek Sequel
items.articleTeaser: An Indiegogo campaign aims to put a video about the country's space program in prime summer blockbuster ad space.

items.keywords: drones, Global Hawk, weather, natural disasters, UAVs, nasa, hurricanes
items.articleName: Why NASA is Flying Drones Into Hurricanes
items.articleTeaser: Starting this fall, NASA will begin flying Global Hawk UAVs over the tops of swirling hurricanes and on data-gathering missions to where these storms get their start.

items.keywords: mars, air and space, Curiosity Rover, nasa, Mars Rover
items.articleName: NASA Engineer Explains the Audacious Plan to Land Curiosity on Mars
items.articleTeaser: On August 5, when the Mars Science Laboratory reaches the fourth planet, it will deliver the car-sized Curiosity rover to the surface through an audacious, complicated method called Sky Crane. From a hovering rocket-powered platform, cables will lower Curiosity to the surface. We asked Steve Sell, an entry, descent and landing engineer at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory who has worked on the project for six years, how the crazy idea came about.

items.keywords: RFP, nasa, Boeing, private spaceflight, human spaceflight, spacex, sierra nevada, Philip McAlister
items.articleName: Interview: NASA’s New Rules for Manned Private Spaceflight
items.articleTeaser: Our report on NASA’s new contract detailing the rules for crew-carrying spacecraft features the insights of Philip McAlister, director of NASA’s Commercial Spaceflight Development. Here, we offer the full transcript of our Oct. 12 interview with McAlister, in which he details how NASA is trying to change the way it does business. (Light edits were made for clarity.)

items.keywords: nasa, 3D Printing, Space Launch System, space travel, SLS
items.articleName: 3D Printers to Build NASA Rockets
items.articleTeaser: Charles Bolden, NASA administrator and former astronaut, praises the potential of 3D printing to one day quickly create any parts that space travelers would need, and do it with material from whatever planet, moon, or asteroid they happen to inhabit.

items.keywords: nasa, Beam, Bigelow Aerospace, iss, private space, International Space Station
items.articleName: Robert Bigelow Talks Inflatable ISS Add-On
items.articleTeaser: Bigelow Aerospace has landed a contract with NASA to install an addition to the ISS for a (relatively) cheap $17.8 million. The low price is made possible in part because the add-on will ride to the station in a compact, tightly folded package and expand to full size after it arrives. CEO Robert Bigelow talks with PM about the contract and his company's future.

items.keywords: nasa, drone, tropopause, atmosphere, Global Hawk
items.articleName: NASA’s Climate Drones Fly to 65,000 Feet
items.articleTeaser: This month marks the start of a five-year mission to collect data from 65,000 feet up—data that might change what we think we know about global warming.

items.keywords: Moon, NASA, rocketry, space, spacecraft
items.articleName: NASA Will Tinker With Open-Source Rocket for Return to Moon
items.articleTeaser: Click here to go behind the scenes of NASA's new Moon spacecraft, and here for an astronaut's take on how to survive the new lunar base.

items.keywords: mercury, nasa, spacecraft, space, messenger
items.articleName: Inside NASA's Mega Flyby of Mercury's Dark Side
items.articleTeaser: Scientists got their first glimpse of Mercury's surface in 33 years when the MESSENGER spacecraft flew by the planet, beaming back fascinating photos of a previously hidden portion of the planet.

items.keywords: Moon, space, spacecraft, NASA, Resident_Astronaut
items.articleName: Lunar Real Estate: NASA's Permanent Moon Base
items.articleTeaser: PLUS: Click here for a take from Tom Jones, PM's Resident Astronaut, on what the moon base will bring.

items.keywords: nasa, sun, solar, observatory, satellite
items.articleName: NASA Solar Observatory Gallery
items.articleTeaser: The $850 million Solar Dynamics Observatory may help scientists find the causes of solar weather events that disrupt technologies on Earth—while taking unprecedented high-resolution pictures of the sun. Here are some of the latest images from the new observatory.

items.keywords: conversation, with, a, garver, nasa, administrator, lori, deputy
items.articleName: A Conversation with NASA's Lori Garver
items.articleTeaser:
NASA deputy administrator Lori Garver, as the second in command at NASA, has been one of the guiding lights for the Obama administration's space policy since he was a candidate. During the presidential transition, before she was confirmed by the Senate, Garver was already engaged in a multitude of meetings to plot a new direction for NASA. 

That new direction, which abandons the Bush administration's orbital rockets and a return to the moon, will soon be put to the test this fall when Congress will debate and vote on NASA's budget. Garver has served as an NASA employee, and an advisor to corporations and politicians, but she has never been faced with such a monumental task—forging a new direction for American space policy. Contributor Rand Simberg exchanged emails with Garver to find out the back story behind the cancellation of the Constellation program, the political fights ahead and how she plans to get human feet on Mars.

items.keywords: the new nasa: a path to anywhere, and everywhere
items.articleName: The New NASA: A Path To Anywere, And Everywhere
items.articleTeaser: Guest space analyst Rand Simberg disagrees with the assessment of PM resident astronaut, Tom Jones who thinks that Obama's budget proposal is on the wrong track—and that NASA, not private space companies, should lead the way back to the moon. Simberg argues that the new path, outlined by the president's budget, holds promise of real progress.

items.keywords: the new nasa: a path to anywhere, and everywhere
items.articleName: The New NASA: A Path To Anywere, And Everywhere
items.articleTeaser: Guest space analyst Rand Simberg disagrees with the assessment of PM resident astronaut, Tom Jones who thinks that Obama's budget proposal is on the wrong track—and that NASA, not private space companies, should lead the way back to the moon. Simberg argues that the new path, outlined by the president's budget, holds promise of real progress.

items.keywords: space, nasa, private space, president obama
items.articleName: Human Space Flight Needn't Rely on NASA: Guest Analysis
items.articleTeaser: Is Obama's just-released NASA budget the "death march for the future of U.S. human space flight," as Senator Richard Shelby proclaims on his website today? Or is it in fact a new beginning for the space agency?

items.keywords: Hubble, nasa, imax, telescopes, spacecraft, movies, filmmaking, 3D
items.articleName: NASA's Hubble Is Ready for Its 3D Closeup
items.articleTeaser: When astronauts fixed the Hubble space telescope in May 2009, they also moonlighted as 3D cinematographers. Catch some of their footage (in 2D) on this new Hubble 3D trailer.

items.keywords: space, ares, nasa, spacecraft
items.articleName: Rooting for NASA's Ares I Rockets: Analysis
items.articleTeaser: A week of spaceflight tests, large and small, reminds us why NASA's much maligned launch vehicle is important. If it fails, we lose the moon.

items.keywords: mars, Curiosity Rover, water, nasa
items.articleName: Remnants of Stream Found on Mars
items.articleTeaser: NASA's Curiosity rover found evidence for an ancient, flowing stream on Mars at a few sites. The key evidence for the ancient stream comes from the size and rounded shape of the gravel in and around the bedrock.

items.keywords: nasa, asteroid, president obama, congress, asteroids, asteroid capture
items.articleName: Maybe NASA Won't Grab That Asteroid
items.articleTeaser: President Obama's plan for NASA to capture an asteroid gets bogged down in Congress.

items.keywords: telescopes, asteroids, astronomy
items.articleName: How We'll Detect Dangerous Asteroids
items.articleTeaser: Zeljko Ivezic has been an astronomer since the third grade. Since becoming an astronomy professor, he's worked on the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) to map a quarter of the night sky and catalog more than 500 million objects. Today, Ivezic is the project scientist for the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), which will scan the entire night sky twice a week when it becomes operational in 2021. With its unprecedented ability to detect faint and fast-moving objects, LSST will help fulfill NASA's congressional mandate to identify and map 90 percent of near-Earth objects more than 140 meters wide.

items.keywords: asteroids, 2012 DA14, nasa, asteroid impacts
items.articleName: How to Save Earth From Asteroids
items.articleTeaser: Humanity is in no danger from the asteroid that will buzz our planet tomorrow. But, astronaut and PM contributor Tom Jones says, the flyby is a dramatic reminder that we need to do much more to track the asteroids in our neighborhood, just in case there is one on an impact course.

items.keywords: platinum, space, mining, x prize, spacecraft, solar system, google, robots, asteroids
items.articleName: Should We Mine the Moon or Asteroids?
items.articleTeaser: Planetary Resources made a media splash recently by announcing a plan to mine asteroids for metals and water. But those same materials are available on the moon, too, and other would-be extraterrestrial prospectors are eyeing lunar missions. So which target is more promising? PM contributor Rand Simberg looks into it here.

items.keywords: nasa, telescopes, defense, asteroids, apophis, Tom Jones
items.articleName: Administration to NASA: Defend Earth from Asteroids, Please
items.articleTeaser: Apophis was just the beginning. There could be as many as a million space rocks near enough to hit the Earth—and, in some cases, take out major population centers. Where's the asteroid czar who will finally mount a cohesive planetary defense?

items.keywords: obama, breakthrough awards, soccket, barack obama, president obama, energy-creating soccer ball
items.articleName: Obama Heads Power-Producing Soccer Ball
items.articleTeaser: President Obama plays with Soccket, a 2010 PopMech Breakthrough Award winner, while on a diplomatic trip to Africa.

items.keywords: UAVs, drones, president barack obama
items.articleName: How Obama Criticized—and Defended—His Own Drone War
items.articleTeaser: The Obama administration offers a critique and defense of its own armed, unmanned-aerial-vehicle bombing campaign.

items.keywords: Corporate Average Fuel Economy, fuel economy, detroit, cafe standards, president barack obama, White House, washington, government, auto industry
items.articleName: Why 54.5 Mpg Doesn't Really Mean 54.5 Mpg
items.articleTeaser: The new CAFE standards for the U.S. auto fleet's average fuel economy set an aggressive goal: 54.5 mpg by 2025, with yearly 5 percent increases to get us there. But a close look at the numbers shows that the real-world performance of our future cars won't be nearly that impressive. In fact, car insiders say, 54.5 mpg really means 40 mpg.

items.keywords: Corporate Average Fuel Economy, fuel economy, detroit, cafe standards, president barack obama, White House, washington, government, auto industry
items.articleName: Obama's New Standard: 54.5 mpg by 2025
items.articleTeaser: The new Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standard is now official, and it's aggressive. Today, President Obama announced that the CAFE standard would increase from a target of 35.5 mpg in 2016 to 54.5 mpg by 2025.

items.keywords: unveiling, new, a, obama's, nasa:, of, controversial, analysis
items.articleName: Obama's New NASA: Analysis
items.articleTeaser: One thing is certain to come from Obama's speech today on the direction of the U.S. space agency: Major changes are coming to NASA. Space analyst Rand Simberg weighs in on this big day for U.S. space policy.

items.keywords: obama, nuclear weapons
items.articleName: Obama: Ban Nukes, Fund Modernized Weapons
items.articleTeaser: President Barack Obama has pledged to work toward a nuclear-weapon-free world. So why is his defense budget filled with money to modernize the things that carry them?

items.keywords: military, pentagon, President_Obama, weapons, aircraft
items.articleName: 3 Programs That Lose Out in Obama's Defense Budget
items.articleTeaser: The Obama administration released its budget and strategy documents this week, spelling trouble for some military programs. Not that many are at risk of cancellation, though: The $708 billion 2011 Pentagon budget is $18 billion higher than 2010's. (It calls for $33 billion in supplemental funding for wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, something candidate Barack Obama railed against during his campaign.) Still, Gates and Obama took some programs to task, and killed one outright. Here's a rundown of some of the losers.

items.keywords: nasa, government, Space Shuttle, president obama, private space
items.articleName: 5 Winners in Obama's Space Budget
items.articleTeaser: With Congress and NASA-watchers obsessed with the Obama administration's attempted sacking of the Constellation moonshot program, and the resultant slack taken up by private space companies, other shifts have been lost in the noise. Here are some winners and losers in the proposed budget, which still has to face the Congressional gauntlet.

items.keywords: science, education, Dean_Kamen, Barack_Obama, technology, Mythbusters, FIRST_Robotics
items.articleName: Obama Pushes For Improved Science and Technology Education
items.articleTeaser: It was a fitting finale to a press event organized to announce new initiatives in science and technology education, a 6-foot-tall FIRST Robotics competitor whirred to life, shooting neon balls from a compressed-air tube past the President.

items.keywords: government, infrastructure, solar_power, electricity, alternative_energy, Barack_Obama
items.articleName: Obama Announces Winners of Smart-Grid Stimulus
items.articleTeaser: Today, President Barack Obama spoke at Florida Power and Light's new DeSoto Next Generation Solar Energy Center about $3.4 billion in stimulus money going to smart-grid projects that will help link renewables to consumers.

items.keywords: nasa, spacecraft, private_space, legislation, Space_Shuttle, Barack_Obama
items.articleName: An Astronaut's Letter to President Obama: Six Space Policy Musts
items.articleTeaser: The future of NASA is being decided now. But will there be enough financial support to move U.S. lunar program forward on pace? Astronaut Tom Jones, writing for PM, pled the administration to maintain funding for the lunar mission to stay on target. There are already signs that some of his advice may not be heeded and that the moon might just be off the table out as a NASA destination by 2020.

items.keywords: Internet, Barack_Obama, legislation, government, software
items.articleName: New Obama Appointee May Promote Off-the-rack Software Within the U.S. Government
items.articleTeaser: The Obama administration tapped Vivek Kundra to be the federal government's first CIO yesterday. Kundra was the Chief Information Officer for Washington, D.C., and should not be confused with Obama's long-promised Chief Technology Officer, who has still not yet been named. But based on Kundra's previous experience and comments thus far, he could have a pretty significant impact on the government's use of technology.

items.keywords: minerals, Future of Space, air and space, asteroids, deep space, asteroid mining
items.articleName: The Tech We'll Need to Mine Asteroids
items.articleTeaser: To tap the riches of space, first we'll need to build up ambitious infrastructure, such as fuel depots, and tools to work on asteroids, such as low-gravity sifters.

items.keywords: minerals, Future of Space, air and space, asteroids, deep space, asteroid mining
items.articleName: The Tech We'll Need to Mine Asteroids
items.articleTeaser: To tap the riches of space, first we'll need to build up ambitious infrastructure, such as fuel depots, and tools to work on asteroids, such as low-gravity sifters.

items.keywords: arab spring, russia, vladimir putin, libya, PRISM, Edward Snowden, obama, cold war, nsa
items.articleName: 5 Reasons Russia Helped Edward Snowden
items.articleTeaser: Edward Snowden has left the Moscow airport, having been granted a year of temporary asylum by the Russian government. If you’re wondering why Putin would antagonize the U.S. like this, allow us to catch you up on the reasons Moscow-Washington relations have been a bit frosty of late.

items.keywords: military, government, u.s. army, barack obama, homeless, veteran
items.articleName: How Does Washington Count America's Homeless Vets?
items.articleTeaser: The Obama administration recently said that the number of homeless veterans dropped by 12 percent from 2010 to 2011. But getting accurate counts of the homeless is extremely difficult, and the government changed its counting methods during the year of the reported drop. Is the number of homeless vets really going down, or is the drop an artifact of murky statistics?

items.keywords: Future of Space, air and space, asteroids, deep space, asteroid mining, minerals
items.articleName: Who Has the Right to Mine an Asteroid?
items.articleTeaser: As PopMech has relentlessly covered, the race is on to tap the mineral wealth tucked away in the asteroids. But are these big space rocks free for the taking, or will asteroid miners find themselves bogged down in outer space red tape? Instapundit blogger and resident contrarian Glenn Harlan Reynolds investigates.

items.keywords: asteroids, global warming, nuclear missiles, black holes, natural disasters, meteors, robots, pandemic, volcanoes, solar storms, ice age, doomsday, 2012, disease, CERN, Robotics, worst-case-scenario
items.articleName: 12 Ways the World Could (Really) End in 2012
items.articleTeaser: Forget the Mayan nonsense. Goofy prophecies and Mesoamerican calendars won't bring about the end of civilization, but there are at least a dozen scientifically valid ways the apocalypse could arrive before 2012 is out.

items.keywords: science, education, Dean_Kamen, Barack_Obama, technology, Mythbusters, FIRST_Robotics
items.articleName: Obama Pushes For Improved Science and Technology Education
items.articleTeaser: It was a fitting finale to a press event organized to announce new initiatives in science and technology education, a 6-foot-tall FIRST Robotics competitor whirred to life, shooting neon balls from a compressed-air tube past the President.

items.keywords: education, education 2.0
items.articleName: Why "Work Smart, Not Hard" is the Worst Advice in the World
items.articleTeaser: Work smarter, not harder? Don't tell it to Dirty Jobs host Mike Rowe, who meets some of the hardest-working people in America. In fact, he argues, that mantra is the opposite of the attitude we need to beat this lousy economy.

items.keywords: education, online university, education 2.0
items.articleName: Education 2.0: Fixing the Broken Higher-Ed System
items.articleTeaser: Tuition is rising. Graduates, burdened by the incredible debt required to get a four-year degree, can't find jobs. It's time to hack your education.

items.keywords: online university, education, tech careers, education 2.0, y combinator, online courses, tech jobs
items.articleName: 6 Tech Career Paths That Won't Bury You in Debt
items.articleTeaser: Four-year colleges too often overcharge and under-deliver. How about a different plan? Here are six creative new (and relatively inexpensive) paths to great tech careers.

items.keywords: college, UAV, education, drone
items.articleName: Dear Old Drone U.: UAVs Go to College
items.articleTeaser: Universities around America are opening a new line of study: training for students to become unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) pilots and mechanics.

items.keywords: auto safety, driving schools, education, driving tips
items.articleName: 5 Tips to Survive Simple Emergencies on the Road
items.articleTeaser: Here are some potentially catastrophic driving situations that can be turned into quickly forgotten incidents with simple, but effective, action. For most, passengers can save the day. PM contributor Mac Demere, a former racing driver and driving instructor, offers a few simple tips to keep you alive out there.

For most, passengers can save the day. PM contributor Mac Demere, a former racing driver and driving instructor, offers a few simple tips to keep you alive out there.

items.keywords: education, driving tips, auto safety, driving schools
items.articleName: 4 Things You Didn't Learn in Driver's Ed
items.articleTeaser: PM contributor Mac Demere teaches at an advanced driving school for teens, trying to prep the next generation of motorists for road-going emergencies they didn't learn about in driver's ed. Here are five things that newly minted drivers—and the rest of us, frankly­—need to learn.

items.keywords: learning, museum, science, research, education, math, new york city
items.articleName: 6 Ways to Expand Your Mind at the Math Museum
items.articleTeaser: Please don't touch the exhibit! Just kidding. The Museum of Mathematics, which opens Dec. 15 in New York City, encourages kids and adults to experiment with the installations on display. PM got an early look inside. Here are some of our favorites.

items.keywords: learning, museum, science, research, education, math, new york city
items.articleName: 6 Ways to Expand Your Mind at the Math Museum
items.articleTeaser: Please don't touch the exhibit! Just kidding. The Museum of Mathematics, which opens Dec. 15 in New York City, encourages kids and adults to experiment with the installations on display. PM got an early look inside. Here are some of our favorites.

items.keywords: education, Robotics, dean kamen, robots, engineering, FIRST Robotics
items.articleName: High School Students Turn Inventors
items.articleTeaser: The students who compete in FIRST Robotics every year build amazing mechanical creations, but now those students are turned their creativity and know-how into real patented inventions.

items.keywords: diy, toys, education, new york city, gadgets, toy fair 2012
items.articleName: The Coolest Gadgets of Toy Fair 2012
items.articleTeaser: Toy Fair is one of our favorite events of the year because the event floor is crawling with cool tech-y toys and gadgets. Here are 12 of the best we saw at this year's show.

items.keywords: college, education, college bubble, student loans, college debt, skilled trades
items.articleName: Can Tech Fix the College Debt Crisis?
items.articleTeaser: Student loan debt is spiraling out of control, and the trend can't go on forever. Could skilled trades like electrical work and plumbing be part of the answer? They face a shortage of qualified workers, and these fields pay wages that compare favorably to those earned by college grads.

items.keywords: science, education, engineering, FIRST Robotics, technology, robots, dean kamen
items.articleName: 12 Coolest Robots from the 2011 FIRST Championship
items.articleTeaser: High school robotics teams descended upon St. Louis this weekend for the FIRST championships. In the event's first year in the Gateway City, FIRST Robotics Championship teams competed in the Logo Motion event: building robots capable of grabbing delicate inflatable tubes and hanging them on pegs, sometimes autonomously. As usual, the student engineers came up with some wild and amazing designs.

items.keywords: science, education, engineering, FIRST Robotics, technology, robots, dean kamen

items.keywords: obama, nuclear weapons
items.articleName: Obama: Ban Nukes, Fund Modernized Weapons
items.articleTeaser: President Barack Obama has pledged to work toward a nuclear-weapon-free world. So why is his defense budget filled with money to modernize the things that carry them?

items.keywords: icebreakers, nuclear power
items.articleName: Inside Russia's Floating Reactors
items.articleTeaser: Russia plans to built floating reactors that can dock at remote Arctic cities to provide energy and fresh water. Here's how they work.

items.keywords: environment, ivory, black-market, animals, elephants, nuclear fallout
items.articleName: Using Nuclear Fallout to Stop Black-Market Ivory
items.articleTeaser: As elephant poaching reaches an all-time high, researchers have discovered a way to single out black-market ivory by using Cold War-era radiation.

items.keywords: nuclear energy, chernobyl, nuclear power, proliferation, Fukushima, energy
items.articleName: When Greens Embrace Nuclear Power
items.articleTeaser: Robert Stone's new documentary, out today in New York and this weekend around the country, follows environmentalists who have reached the same difficult conclusion he has: When it comes to generating electricity, nuclear power is only practical way to wean the world off fossil fuels.

items.keywords: nuclear power, next-gen energy, nuclear, nuclear energy
items.articleName: Take a Look Inside a Tiny Nuclear Reactor
items.articleTeaser: This year Westinghouse will begin fuel tests for its Small Modular Reactor (SMR), a downsized system that puts out 225 megawatts.

items.keywords: nuclear power, next-gen energy, fusion, Why Don't We Have
items.articleName: Why Don't We Have Fusion Power?
items.articleTeaser: Why Don't We Have is a PopMech series that seeks to quickly explain just why some of the technologies promised by science fiction have yet to become fact. Today: fusion power.

items.keywords: earthquakes, AAAS, geology, nuclear Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
items.articleName: Nuke Test Ban Treaty: A Boon for Science?
items.articleTeaser: The monitoring stations set up to enforce the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty could also help scientists to better understand earthquakes and the makeup of the Earth's interior.

items.keywords: japan, tsunami, Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant, earthquakes, Fukushima, 2011 Japan earthquake
items.articleName: How Japan's Quake Transformed a Fault
items.articleTeaser: Nearly two years after the devastating magnitude 9.0 earthquake and tsunami, researchers are one step closer to figuring out the geology of Japan's incredible natural disaster.

items.keywords: nuclear energy, Thorium, nuclear weapons, proliferation
items.articleName: Superfuel Thorium a Proliferation Risk?
items.articleTeaser: A new study in Nature says that using thorium as a nuclear fuel has a higher risk for proliferation into weapons than scientists had believed.

items.keywords: aircraft carriers, military, star trek, US Navy, navy vessels, nuclear power, ships, USS Enterprise
items.articleName: The Towering Legacy of the USS Enterprise
items.articleTeaser: As America's first and greatest nuclear-powered aircraft carrier approaches retirement, we recount the highlights of its half-century at sea.

items.keywords: subs, Pacific Theatre, china, nuclear subs
items.articleName: What China’s Nuclear Missile Subs Mean for the U.S.
items.articleTeaser: China is on track to field nuclear weapons on submarines in two years, according to U.S. government reports. But don’t start restocking the fallout shelters just yet.

items.keywords: earthquake, seismology, nuclear weapons, north korea
items.articleName: Did North Korea Really Test a Nuke in 2010?
items.articleTeaser: North Korea shocked the world in 2006 and 2008 when it detonated nuclear warheads in underground chambers. So when Lars-Erik De Geer, a researcher with the Swedish Defense Research Agency, published a paper early this year claiming evidence of low-yield nuclear detonations in 2010, it seemed feasible. His evidence is a spike in radionuclides—isotopes of xenon and argon that are produced by a nuclear weapon—picked up by detectors in Asia. There was one problem with the theory: Nuclear detonations shake seismic monitors, and scientists at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory who looked at his paper found no evidence of a sufficiently large explosion, throwing the existence of a clandestine test in doubt. We talked to Paul Richards of Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, who co-authored the paper questioning De Geer’s conclusions. (We also tried to talk to De Greer but were told by staff at the Swedish Defense Research Agency that he was retired and "cannot be reached.")

items.keywords: Nuclear deterrence, LRSB, b-2 bomber, b-1 bomber
items.articleName: The State of U.S. Nuke Deterrence
items.articleTeaser: Air Force Lt. Gen. James M. Kowalski, leader of Global Strike Command, is in charge of some of the nation’s more lethal weapons. No minor task, that—the fleets of the B-2 and B-52 bombers and Minuteman III ICBMs are aging, budget cuts are looming, and more nations are becoming nuclear powers. Still, Kowalski took time to visit PM’s offices in New York City to talk about the challenges facing GSC, a program to base nuclear missiles, the creation of a new bomber, and other ways to keep America’s ultimate weapons ready in the future.

items.keywords: Biological Weapons, apple, nuclear weapons, social media, Chemical Weapons, U.S. Government, facebook, Twitter, weapons_of_mass_destruction
items.articleName: US Tries Arms Control Through Social Media
items.articleTeaser: The new "innovation in arms control" challenge will offer $10,000 for the best idea for using social media to catch countries that violate arms control agreements.

items.keywords: nuclear energy, spacecraft, fusion, spaceships
items.articleName: A Big Step for Fusion Spaceships
items.articleTeaser: Some scientists are hopeful that fusion—the sun’s nearly limitless source of energy—may one day enable deep space exploration and interstellar travel.

items.keywords: environment, engineering, nuclear waste, earth, finland, nuclear energy, Waste disposal
items.articleName: Finland's Crazy Plan to Make Nuclear Waste Disappear
items.articleTeaser: The U.S. plan to bury nuclear waste in Yucca Mountain may be dead, but in Finland, engineers are going ahead with a plan to build an enormous bunker to house the dangerous stuff. And they have a radical solution to keep future civilizations away—hide the nuclear waste somewhere so unremarkable and unpleasant that nobody would ever think to go there.

items.keywords: worst-case-scenario, robots, tsunami, nuclear energy, Fukushima, earthquake, Robotics, natural disaster
items.articleName: 3 Robots That Braved Fukushima
items.articleTeaser: When the radiation levels coming from the ruined Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan were too high to safely allow humans to enter, robots went in first. Here are three that played a major part in monitoring the plant during the emergency-response period and showing to their human operators the level of devastation inside.

items.keywords: Fukushima, small modular reactors, nuclear power, doe, SMR, NuScale, nuclear, nuclear energy
items.articleName: Next Up in Nuclear: Small Modular Reactors
items.articleTeaser: The Obama administration’s next move in boosting energy techonlogy will be nearly $500 million in support of small modular reactors. Individually, these nuclear reactors would produce less energy than traditional reactors, but could be used more flexibly and operate more efficiently. Here’s what to know about the next thing in nuclear.

items.keywords: north korea, military, military news, china, nuclear weapons, south korea, syria, iraq, middle east, asia
items.articleName: North Korea and Two More Hotspots to Watch
items.articleTeaser: Three of the world's most combustible regions are flaring as 2011 comes to an end. Here are the battles, civil wars, and massacres to keep an eye on over eggnog.

items.keywords: research, nuclear energy, next-gen energy, engineering, fusion, fission
items.articleName: Is Fusion Power Finally For Real?
items.articleTeaser: For decades now, a rosy future fueled by cheap, unlimited energy has always been just a few years away. Now, fusion programs including scrappy startups and billion-dollar government labs have taken the first steps toward generating star power.

items.keywords: energy crisis, electric, naturl gas, power, nuclear energy, grid, next-gen energy, oil, superconductor, diesel, fusion
items.articleName: 10 Fixes For the New Energy Crisis
items.articleTeaser: The U.S. can't wait decades for exotic technology like fusion to save us from our energy woes. We've got to start now, and these 10 common-sense ideas for the immediate, midterm and long term future can get us going in the right direction.

items.keywords: energy, swimming pools, fossil fuels, power plants, nuclear energy, cooling tech
items.articleName: Swimming Pool to Cool Nuclear Power Plant?
items.articleTeaser: Inspired by the enormous swimming pools he builds as part of his real estate business, Chilean biochemist Fernando Fischmann and his company, Crystal Lagoons Corp., have devised a new design for a power plant cooling system. It recycles and cleans the water rather than dumping it out to sea and endangering wildlife.

items.keywords: Attack, Nuclear, New York City, SXSW, The Divide, 2011
items.articleName: Nuke Attack on New York City in The Divide
items.articleTeaser: In The Divide, nuclear missiles flatten New York, driving a group of survivors into the bunker underneath their apartment building—formerly the domain of their ornery building superintendent Mickey (Michael Biehn). Trapped, the inhabitants become more and more savage as the isolation gets to them, and as radiation poisoning destroys their bodies and minds. Popular Mechanics sat down with director Xavier Gens and Biehn to talk about the idea for the film, and how to craft an unforgettable vision of post-nuclear New York.

items.keywords: Attack, Nuclear, New York City, SXSW, The Divide, 2011
items.articleName: Nuke Attack on New York City in The Divide
items.articleTeaser: In The Divide, nuclear missiles flatten New York, driving a group of survivors into the bunker underneath their apartment building—formerly the domain of their ornery building superintendent Mickey (Michael Biehn). Trapped, the inhabitants become more and more savage as the isolation gets to them, and as radiation poisoning destroys their bodies and minds. Popular Mechanics sat down with director Xavier Gens and Biehn to talk about the idea for the film, and how to craft an unforgettable vision of post-nuclear New York.

items.keywords: diy, sxsw, behind-the-scenes, movies, Digital_Hollywood, South by Southwest 2011
items.articleName: How to Fund & Shoot Your Homemade Movie
items.articleTeaser: What if bloodthirsty vampires turned your favorite sci-fi convention into an all-you-can-eat buffet, and your crush-turned-vampire accidentally made you one of them in the process? Welcome to My Sucky Teen Romance, by 18-year-old writer/director Emily Hagins. She talked to Popular Mechanics about how she pulled off the visual effects on a shoestring budget and raised the money to shoot the film through the fund-raising website IndieGoGo.com.

items.keywords: letterpress, Android, SXSWi, sxsw 2013, sxsw, foursquare, iphone apps, Yelp, facebook
items.articleName: The Bizarre World of App Release Notes
items.articleTeaser: Nobody wants to have the buggy app that all the assembled geeks at South by Southwest bemoan. As the Texas tech festival heats up, app-makers are trying to grab attention and avoid embarrassment by flooding app stores with updates.

items.keywords: Law, patents, Makerbots, sxsw, 3D Printing, intellectual property
items.articleName: Legal Battles Loom Over 3D Printing
items.articleTeaser: Like any disruptive technology, 3D printing could spark lawsuits from those who aren't too happy about their technology being displaced, attorney Michael Weinberg explained at South by Southwest.

items.keywords: movies, documentary, science fiction, sxsw 2012, film, sci-fi, Digital_Hollywood, South By Southwest 2012
items.articleName: The 12 Movies You Need to See at SXSW 2012
items.articleTeaser: Some of the geekiest movies of 2012 are debuting at South by Southwest this week. We talked to some of the filmmakers and actors behind the titles we're most excited to see this year. Check back here as we update the story with more movies.

items.keywords: movies, documentary, science fiction, sxsw 2012, film, sci-fi, Digital_Hollywood, South By Southwest 2012
items.articleName: The 12 Movies You Need to See at SXSW 2012
items.articleTeaser: Some of the geekiest movies of 2012 are debuting at South by Southwest this week. We talked to some of the filmmakers and actors behind the titles we're most excited to see this year. Check back here as we update the story with more movies.

items.keywords: movies, documentary, science fiction, sxsw 2012, film, sci-fi, Digital_Hollywood, South By Southwest 2012
items.articleName: The 12 Movies You Need to See at SXSW 2012
items.articleTeaser: Some of the geekiest movies of 2012 are debuting at South by Southwest this week. We talked to some of the filmmakers and actors behind the titles we're most excited to see this year. Check back here as we update the story with more movies.

items.keywords: sxsw, tweets, arab spring, Egypt, Twitter, mubarak
items.articleName: Twitter: From Stream of Consciousness to Tool of Revolution
items.articleTeaser: Speakers at South by Southwest 2012 are obsessed with social media's role in fomenting revolution.

items.keywords: doomsday, 2012, Mayans, sxsw, sxsw 2012, endtimes
items.articleName: SXSW: Why 2012 Doomsday Predictions are Bogus
items.articleTeaser: Astronomer Phil Plait explains why the world won't end on Dec. 21, 2012.

items.keywords: sxsw, Apps, iPad games, cats, ipad
items.articleName: PM vs. Cat in iPad Showdown
items.articleTeaser: Popular Mechanics Associate Editor/cat fancier Erin McCarthy is at South by Southwest this week, where she found the perfect iPad game to play against your feline.

items.keywords: tweeting, Law, Twitter, tweets, sxsw, social media
items.articleName: Yes, You Can Be Sued Over a Tweet
items.articleTeaser: It seems 140 characters are enough to get a person in legal trouble. Here are some tips to keep you from tweeting your way into a courtroom, courtesy of communications expert Dana Quackenbush, who spoke here at South by Southwest.

items.keywords: diy, sxsw, behind-the-scenes, movies, Digital_Hollywood, South by Southwest 2011
items.articleName: What are the Secrets of Another Earth?
items.articleTeaser: In Another Earth, 17-year-old Rhoda Williams—who has plans to go to MIT to study astrophysics—spots an unbelievable sight in the night sky: a tiny speck that scientists say is a second Earth, identical to our own. The film, which debuted at Sundance and had a secret screening at SXSW in March, will come out later this year. We sat down with writer/star Brit Marling (whose other film, Sound of My Voice, also played at both Sundance and SXSW) and star William Mapother to discuss the science behind the film and whether they would take a trip to Earth 2.

items.keywords: documentary, sxsw, South by Southwest 2011, q&a, Digital_Hollywood
items.articleName: Dutch Artist Mechanically Reanimates Dead Animals
items.articleTeaser: At a Portuguese convent that his family has spent a quarter-century restoring, Dutch kinetic artist Christiaan Zwanikken reanimates naturally preserved animal skins and bones using mechanical parts he culls from garbage dumps. In the film Convento (which is still seeking distribution), director Jarred Alterman captures the haunting energy and mechanical splendor of these works of art. We sat down with Alterman at SXSW to discuss the art of DIY filmmaking, and Zwanikken emailed Popular Mechanics from Paris about the inspiration for—and the creation of—his unique art.

items.keywords: diy, sxsw, behind-the-scenes, movies, Digital_Hollywood, South by Southwest 2011
items.articleName: How Your Favorite Gadgets Were Saved From Oblivion
items.articleTeaser: We may know every app and function on our laptops and iPhones, but do we know how close these now-ubiquitous devices came to never existing in the first place? The SXSW documentary Something Ventured examines the creation of companies such as Fairchild Semiconductor, Cisco, Atari and Apple, as well as the visionary venture capitalists—among them Bill Edwards, Pitch Johnson and Don Valentine—who took the risk to fund them and allowed something great to blossom. Executive producer Molly Davis and directors Dayna Goldfine and Daniel Geller walk us through bringing these incredible stories to the screen.

items.keywords: movies, sxsw, South by Southwest 2011, q&a, Digital_Hollywood
items.articleName: APART Medical Fact vs. Fiction: SXSW 2011
items.articleTeaser: In Apart, best friends Emily and Noah are afflicted with a rare psychological disorder known as folie à deux—in which two people who share a trauma also share destructive delusions. Director Aaron Rottinghaus and producer/star Josh Danziger sat down with Popular Mechanics at SXSW to talk about the disorder and their painstaking work to get the medical facts right.

items.keywords: movies, sxsw, South by Southwest 2011, q&a, Digital_Hollywood
items.articleName: Five Time Champion Is a Geek's Coming-of-Age Story
items.articleTeaser: n Five Time Champion, written and directed by Bernt Mader, teenage scientist Julius tries in vain to makes the interpersonal drama of his small Texas town work out as neatly as an equation, and searches for the meaning of life... in the earthworms that are his science project. We sat down with Mader and the film's star, Ryan Akin, at SXSW to discuss what it's like to have worms as your co-stars, finding inspiration in drunken goldfish and why, deep down, everyone is a scientist.

items.keywords: diy, sxsw, behind-the-scenes, movies, Digital_Hollywood, South by Southwest 2011
items.articleName: Director James Gunn on his DIY Superhero
items.articleTeaser: Think Batman is the ultimate DIY superhero? Think again. While Bruce Wayne might create cool weapons for his alter ego, the Crimson Bolt, played by Rainn Wilson in Super, actually fights with a pipe wrench. We talked to director James Gunn at SXSW about self-made superheroes and why Crimson Bolt uses a hand tool as his weapon of choice.

items.keywords: diy, sxsw, behind-the-scenes, movies, Digital_Hollywood, South by Southwest 2011
items.articleName: The Web Shorts that Predict the Future!
items.articleTeaser: In the second season of the FUTURESTATES series, ten directors take modern worries such as designer babies, global warming and too much information moving to the cloud, and predict the consequences decades into the future. Beginning this week, one short film will hit futurestates.tv every Wednesday. Six of them screened at this year's SXSW, where Popular Mechanics spoke to series manager Karim Ahmad and to Robby Henson, director of the short Asparagus.

items.keywords: jobs, hiring, South By Southwest Interactive, technology, unemployment, SXSWi, start-ups, new york city
items.articleName: Now Hiring: Tech Jobs at SXSWi 2011
items.articleTeaser: We've grown accustomed to hearing stories on the lousy unemployment rates and lack of job creation over the last few years. But the SXSW festival reveals one sector of the economy that's hiring: Tech companies need engineers and programmers, and lots of them.

items.keywords: movies, sxsw, South by Southwest 2011, q&a, Digital_Hollywood
items.articleName: Joe Cornish and Edgar Wright Attack the Block
items.articleTeaser: In director Joe Cornish's debut feature film, a gang of kids in south London must defend their home, a building they call The Block, from invading bestial aliens. Cornish and executive producer Edgar Wright sat down with Popular Mechanics at SXSW to tell us their inspiration for this extraterrestrial confrontation.

items.keywords: movies, q&a, sxsw, South by Southwest 2011, film, science fiction, Digital Hollywood
items.articleName: Jake Gyllenhaal Talks Source Code at SXSW Premiere
items.articleTeaser: In Source Code, Capt. Colter Stevens (Jake Gyllenhaal) must use a computer program to access, and gather clues from, the last 8 minutes of another man's life to avert a terrible tragedy—and do it over and over again until he gets it right. The film, director Duncan Jones' follow-up to Moon, opens April 1. But the cast and crew brought Source Code down to SXSW, where Popular Mechanics sat down with them to talk about the inspiration for the movie, the challenges during filming, and the weird science behind reliving the past.

items.keywords: ipad, technology, South By Southwest Interactive, google, Android, Apps, SXSWi, iphone, Facebook texting, foursquare, Twitter
items.articleName: SXSWi 2011 and the Future of Social Media
items.articleTeaser: When a horde of tech first-adopters pours into Austin, Texas, for the South by Southwest conference, the possibilities (and headaches) of social media’s next stage come into focus.

items.keywords: South by Southwest 2011, apple, iphone, boxing, SXSWi, video games, gaming, mike tyson
items.articleName: Beat Mike Tyson with Your iPhone
items.articleTeaser: Twenty-four years after the release of Mike Tyson's Punch Out!!, which led Nintendo gamers to spend countless hours practicing the button combos to beat "Iron Mike," Tyson is back on the gaming scene.

items.keywords: technology, sxsw, future, south by southwest
items.articleName: 5 Near-Term Technology Forecasts From Industry Leaders at SXSW
items.articleTeaser: Last month in Austin, Texas, tech nerds, tinkerers and cinephiles gathered at SXSW to discuss the future of technology and film. Here's what they're predicting.

items.keywords: diy, sxsw, behind-the-scenes, movies, Digital_Hollywood, South by Southwest 2011

Welcome to My Sucky Teen Romance, by 18-year-old writer/director Emily Hagins. Executive producer Molly Davis and directors Dayna Goldfine and Daniel Geller walk us through bringing these incredible stories to the screen.

items.keywords: Android, ipad, apple, home improvement, software, Apps, diy, iOS, iphone, applications
items.articleName: The 10 Best Apps for DIYers
items.articleTeaser: For today's do-it-yourselfer, a well-designed smartphone app can be as essential as a hammer and a box of nails. We tested dozens of apps created to help you find lumber, get organized, match paint colors, and more, and settled on the 10 best to save you time and money.

items.keywords: wood, recycling, reclaimed wood, diy, woodworking
items.articleName: Where to Find Reclaimed Wood
items.articleTeaser: Salvaged older wood can add warmth and character to your home—if you know where to look for it.

items.keywords: wood, recycling, reclaimed wood, diy, woodworking
items.articleName: Where to Find Reclaimed Wood
items.articleTeaser: Salvaged older wood can add warmth and character to your home—if you know where to look for it.

items.articleName: Party Popper: Build This Mini-Pyrotechnic
